customer_name: The Tropical Rain Forest Preserve Inc
customer_addr:
163 66th Terrace South
West Palm Beach, FL 33413

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The drug cabinet contained expired medications (dewormer, antibiotics, pain medications, supplements) which were
comingled with non-expired medications ready for use. Expired medical products may lose their effectiveness and may
not assist the animals in recovery from illness and injury or could leave the animals without proper protection against
serious and deadly diseases. Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and prevent
diseases and injuries. Expired medication should be properly disposed. The licensee must ensure that all medical
products being maintained for use at the facility are current and have not expired in order to support the health and well-
being of the animals.

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the contingency plan, record of animals on hand, and environmental enhancement program for
non-human primates were not available for review by the inspector. Review of records required by the Animal Welfare Act
facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to determine compliance and evaluate animal welfare. The
facility shall ensure that the records required to be kept by the Animal Welfare Act and the regulations are available for
USDA APHIS officials to examine at the time of inspection.

The primary enclosure housing two cotton-top tamarins contained two wire mesh platforms which had excessive rust,
deteriorated metal, and sharp points. Sharp points, particularly those in areas that animals frequently contact, increase
the risk of animal injury. The licensee must ensure structural elements shall be sound and in good repair, free from
hazardous conditions such as sharp edges, nails, splinters, or loose, rusty, or deteriorated materials.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 17, 2023, or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The drug cabinet contained expired medications (dewormer, antibiotics, pain medications, supplements) which were 
comingled with non-expired medications ready for use. Expired medical products may lose their effectiveness and may 
not assist the animals in recovery from illness and injury or could leave the animals without proper protection against 
serious and deadly diseases. Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and prevent 
diseases and injuries. Expired medication should be properly disposed. The licensee must ensure that all medical 
products being maintained for use at the facility are current and have not expired in order to support the health and well-
being of the animals. 
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
At the time of inspection, the contingency plan, record of animals on hand, and environmental enhancement program for 
non-human primates were not available for review by the inspector. Review of records required by the Animal Welfare Act 
facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to determine compliance and evaluate animal welfare. The 
facility shall ensure that the records required to be kept by the Animal Welfare Act and the regulations are available for 
USDA APHIS officials to examine at the time of inspection. 
3.80(a)(2)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The primary enclosure housing two cotton-top tamarins contained two wire mesh platforms which had excessive rust, 
deteriorated metal, and sharp points. Sharp points, particularly those in areas that animals frequently contact, increase 
the risk of animal injury. The licensee must ensure structural elements shall be sound and in good repair, free from 
hazardous conditions such as sharp edges, nails, splinters, or loose, rusty, or deteriorated materials. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant.

All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 17, 2023, or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
